description:
Octopus bimaculoides, also known as the California two-spot octopus, is a species of small octopus native to the eastern Pacific Ocean. This species is characterized by its distinctive appearance, which includes two prominent eyespots on its mantle, from which it derives its common name.

Octopus bimaculoides typically ranges in size from 10 to 20 centimeters (4 to 8 inches) in total length, with a relatively short, broad mantle and eight relatively short arms. Its coloration can vary, but it is often reddish-brown or grayish-brown in appearance, with the distinctive eyespots being a contrasting white or pale color.

These octopuses are known to be highly intelligent and adept at problem-solving, as is typical of many octopus species. They are primarily nocturnal and can be found inhabiting rocky, coastal environments, where they use their flexible bodies and camouflage abilities to hunt a variety of small prey, such as crabs, shrimp, and small fish.

Octopus bimaculoides is an important component of the ecosystem in its native range and plays a role in the regulation of populations of its prey species. It is also of interest to marine biologists and other researchers due to its unique behavioral and physiological adaptations.
